1.content:
"Attention, Cadets!" came the clear bark of an officer. Every one of the latest batch of fresh meat saluted and then stood ready. The officer in question was one Sergeant Accipiter. The white pegasus marched his way down the line of ponies. He stopped at one, his harsh eyes glaring down at the already shaking earth pony. "You are all about to start your first day as a real guard. You might expect me to wish you congratulations, say I'm proud... but none of that bucking matters! Each and every one of you just declared your loyalty in a constant war. The battle against crime in a city where the crime rate has doubled in the past year alone!" The pegasus sergeant started moving down the line again. "Look to your left, then look to your right. One of those ponies is not going to come back to their bunk tonight."

There was a collection of muttering and gasps at that one, the pegasus turning and swinging his eyes across the crowd. He settled on a pure white slender looking unicorn who looked very much like he was trying to avoid notice. "You! Name and rank!" Accipiter barked.

The unicorn jumped, but quickly managed to snap it into a salute. "Cadet Lance, sir!" he called back surprisingly smartly.

Accipiter grinned, looking almost predatory himself as he trotted to the space in front of him. "Lance, huh? I'm good friends with your uncle. Good to have you onboard. Do try not to dissappoint your dear dad by ending up the night wedged into the ass crack of a fat mare," the officer said with a chuckle. His eyes then instantly whipped to another pony, this one a thestral mare with a rather pudgy build, especially concentrated on her rear. "You! Name and Rank!"

"Cadet Moon, Sir!" the thestral mare replied with enthusiasm.

"Moon, huh? One of Luna's lot. You'll be on night patrol soon enough. Once this is over head to bed, you'll be woken by Sergeant Nox when it's time," he declared loudly, then he leaned in closer, making sure to whisper so quietly only the two of them would hear it. "And don't wander around the barracks. Some of the guards here love to play with rookies and Thestrals aren't an everyday occurence." His piece said, he leant back, then snapped to another invidual to repeat the process.

Soon enough Accipiter returned to the front, stopping in front of the now much more shaken and less confident crowd. "Each of you is going to start the day off on patrol. It's up to you whether you want to go solo, but I recommend buddying up between yourselves, or with one of the more experienced guardsponies. You can pick your routes off the board, but once a route is picked that's it, can't have you all in one place. And that's all. Dismissed!" Accipiter turned and trotted towards a nearby door, no doubt to his office.

All the rookies milled about, their sudden source of direction gone. Fortunately, or perhaps unfortunately, one of them will be the protagonist of this story, but which of the two should we choose?
1.title: Dawn of the First Day

choices: Lance nods his head. It would be safer with the two of them at least.
Lance shakes his head. A more experienced partner would be better.
Go and ask Accipiter for some kind of help. Lance has no idea what he's doing.
11.content:
Pointed Lance swallowed nervously. This was it. All the regimental training, all those drills, all those tests, and this was it. The second the Sergeant finished his speech he was gone. Sure, Lance was listening, but what was he actually meant to do? Searching around he saw some of the rookies were already pairing up. That thestral mare that had caught his eye had already turned and trotted back to the bunkrooms. For the first time, Lance really actually looked around.

They were in the Royal Guard's Barracks, an attachment to Canterlot Castle. It was pretty large, housing hundreds of active guards at a time, and the single biggest concentration of them in Equestria. The Rookie's had their seperate accomodation, presumably until the next batch arrived and those that remained were moved on to the real barracks. Sergeant Accipiter was the commanding officer for the cadets, and he was in his office right there. Sure, Lance could ask him about what he should be doing... but he seemed pretty terse. He did know Lance's uncle though... the gambling, black sheep of the family uncle but he was still family.

In this room, now the Thestral had left, there were twenty nine royal guard rookies all in their golden armour but with a multitude of fur colours. Already they were starting to seperate out, falling back into the same groups they were in during training. Lance had prefferred to train alone,and now that might be a problem. The light green earth pony that had seen shaking earlier under Accipiter's gaze sidled up to the unicorn, the somewhat chubby stallion giving Lance a weak smile. "Hey there... I'm Camo," he said holding out a hoof. Lance looked at it for a moment before lifting his own and giving it a shake.

"Lance," the unicorn said plainly.

Camo looked at the unicorn expectantly, before Lance just gave a shrug. The earth pony sighed. "Can we... team up?" he asked, his blue eyes seeming to shine as he stared up at the unicorn.
11.title: Following Lance

choices: Noble Quarter. So long as we do as asked, nothing should go wrong.
Market District. It's where most of the rookies will be.
Slums. If anything goes wrong there has to be a place to fall back to.
111.content:
Lance gave the matter a little thought, but really this was his only opportunity. With the others already grouping up if he turned down Camo he might have to go it alone, and anypony was better than nopony. The stallion nodded his head. "Sure. Let's team up."

"Hooray!" Camo cheered, the earth pony suddenly parting his forelegs and pulling Lance into a hug, the unicorn letting out a surprised squeal as he was squished up against the chubby green belly, the faint smell of body odour and sheen of sweat making it even less comfortable.

"P-please get off of me..." Lance asked shakily.

"Oh! Sorry!" Camo replied, releasing Lance and letting the white unicorn flop back onto his rump. Camo gave a grin. "I just got excited, heh. Figured I'd be the odd one out... and I'm pretty sure that guardspony over there has been eyeing me up..." he added, frowning a little as he vaguely gestured with his eyes over his shoulder.

A muscular but also big gutted earth pony stallion was leaning by a doorway, his look most certainly predatory as he glanced over the recruits. He must have been twice the size of Lance... and in every direction. The guard noticed Lance looking, and gave him a wink, before squishing a large hoof against his hanging gut. A swallow came from Lance before he looked back to Camo. "Then it's a good job you came over, heh..."

"Yeah, he give you the look too?" Lance nodded his head and Camo frowned. "Well, let's get out of here quick. So what was the next step?"

Lance nodded his head over towards the large map that other pairs were crowding around. "Time to pick our route."

"Right!" Camo agreed, and a moment later the two of them were trotting over to the nice big map of Canterlot. The crowd of chattering rookies were gathered all around, crowded around it like it was some kind of celebrity. Camo craned his neck upwards, but he couldn't get a good view past a particularly large pony at the front.

Seeing Camo struggle and not wanting to get lumbered with the scraps had Lance push himself forwards. "Excuse me, coming through," he called politely as he threaded between the crowd, and then to the front, sliding in between a pegasus mare and a pegasus stallion. The map was a complete map of Canterlot, marked out nice and clear and split into four distinct sectors, each with a good amount of routes except for the castle itself; it seemed rookies weren't used to patrol there. There were still routes going in each, and Lance managed to snatch the pen with his magic as the pegasus stallion beside him turned away, the unicorn grinning as he moved it to the board. He had to make a quick choice or risk losing out.

The safest from crime, but most dangerous from the public was the regal and wide paved streets of the Noble Quarter. Everypony with a name was sure to have a house there, but thanks to the newest trend of the predator body being in it was no doubt filled with nobles looking for a quick bulk up. They were also known to be demanding and eccentric... a bad combination for any passersby.

Nowhere saw more traffic than the main Market Plaza and the district around it. More guards than any were needed to cover it, meaning that backup would always be close by if it was needed... and it likely would be. Not to mention the well known Black Market that lay beneath the plaza and sold everything and anything.

Lastly was the slums, the place where ponies that weren't rich or tradesponies ended up. Crime was very strong there, courtesy of a mess of gangs and desperation ran high for a lot of the locals. The only real positive there was a maintained guard outpost and several strongrooms, so those that felt threatened had places to fall back to.

"Hurry up already, we've all got places to be!" came a shout from behind Lance, and another pony nudged him in the side. Quickly he put pen to the paper, choosing his route. That done he capped the pen and slid on back through the crowd, emerging with a thump in front of Camo.

The green earth pony looked down at him excitedly. "Nice going, Lance! So where are we going?"
111.title: Find Your Exit Buddy

choices: Head to the right and past the Estate.
Head to the left and through the Gardens.
Maybe you should just chill at the fountain.
1111.content:
It's a short walk for the pair of you to the Noble Quarter, it being the closest district to the castle of course. You quickly passed a few of the grand and stately homes, broken up only by fancy boutiques and cafes. In no time at all you were at the huge fountain that marked the entrance to this rather large area. This piece was commissioned by Blueblood, if the fact a statue of the stallion himself stood triumphantly at the top wasn't a dead giveaway. Supposedly it was to commemorate the defeat of the Changelings in their attempted invasion during the Royal Wedding, yet no accounts actually even put Blueblood in the castle at the time, yet the statue suggested he had commanded battlements in some kind of protracted siege, water firing in jets from carved marble cannons down and into the fountain itself which was full of twisted equine looking figures.

"Look at him... he's such a hero," Camo said wistfully, staring up at the stone statue of the illustrious prince.

Lance blinked once, then twice, before clearing out his ears. "Sorry, could you repeat that, I could have sworn you called Blueblood heroic," the stallion replied with a glance of disbelief.

"Look at this statue and tell me he does not look heroic," Camo was quick to respond, gesturing up at the magnificent figure that Lance just realised was supposed to be crying crystalised tears that were suspended in air by magic.

Lance looked at the statue, then back to Camo, then back to the statue again. "Do you even remember the Canterlot Invasion?" he asked, the look of incredulity etched all over his face.

Camo's response was chiefly a shrug, but Lance's continued look earned some words after a few seconds. "Well... uh... not really... no... I kind of... hid..."

Lance's let out another sigh and then followed up with a shake of his head. "So... moving on... we can't just stand around the Freedom Fountain all day."

"Why not? It's got good, clear views and junk," Camo replied quickly.

Lance was beginning to think he may have chosen a partner too quickly. "Because then we're not patrolling, Camo. We have our route. Both start and end here actually, so it's just which way you want to take first. We go to the right and we'll pass the huge Vorare Estate first, or we stick to the left and through the Faust Memorial Guardians?"

Camo huffed loudly, looking between the two and then shrugging. "Either way we'll walk past them both anyway," he pointed out. "You pick, Lance."
1111.title: The Noblest of Quarters.

11111.content:
The Vorare Estate was probably as good a choice as any. This family was known for gluttony and lavish parties, most of which ended with less ponies leaving than entering. And it was clear when you looked at any members of this family. Each and every single one of them was sporting a huge belly, which the Vorares were very proud of. "Alright Camo, let's stick to the Estate wall and go past as quickly as possible. These nobles are bad news. More so than usual. For now Lance was hoping that, if they appeared busy to any onlookers, they decided not to bug them on their patrol.

So they began their patrol on the right path, where the huge estate was immediately visible. For nobles, houses were not so much homes as they were status symbols. They needed to be big and fancy with beautiful carvings and expertly tended gardens.

"Hey, do you hear that too?" Camo suddenly asked, his ears perking up.

Lance stops for a moment, listening to any possible sound. Indeed there was something going on at the estate. Listening closely it sounds like...
11111.title: Head to the right and past the Estate.

choices: A pony was being pulled on the table
111111.content:
Music was playing and lots of ponies were talking. That became even clearer as they kept walking. The Vorares had one of their gatherings in the garden with classy music, coffee and cakes. This brunch became visible as the two guards stood in front of the gate. A long table was set up in the garden, with Lady Vorare sitting at the prime spot. Directly in front of the chocolate cake. Some paces behind her, a small band was providing the nobles with music. Despite the peaceful scene, there was still a certain tension in the air. The Vorares did not throw a single party without one of the guests ending up in the belly of one of their family members.

Lady Vorare was the matriarch of the family and its most influental member. This mare was massive in size and her chair creaked in protest at the fat ass placed on top of it. Her coat was a light pink with her shining white mane tied into a bun. The golden-yellow eyes always had this predatory gleam wo them.

"Wow, this looks so fancy. Hey, do you think we can get some of that cake?" Camo asked, earning a dumbfounded look from Lance.

It somewhat occured to the unicorn that his choice of partner was wrong. "Camo... these nobles would eat us at the tiniest, perceived slight. Do you seriously think it would be a good idea to just go in there and ask one of the nobles most known for voracious appetite for cake?" Lance asked his partner. Camo would need a crash course in staying alive if Lance wanted to go back to the barracks with partner in tow. Or at all.

Lance looked back at the party scene, ready to urge his partner to advance as he saw something going on in the garden.
111111.title: A party

choices: Maybe there is something we can do.
1111111.content:
A shriek pierced the air as a finely dressed mare was lifted by magic. The glowing around Lady Vorare's horn and a hungry look showed off that the Lady of the house has chosen her next meal. The unfortunate noble was of new wealth, just recently risen up among the ranks. She was younger than Lady Vorare with a white coat and blonde mane. The cream colored summer dress and her pearl necklace were torn away by Lady Vorare as she levitated her meal closer. Her victim screamed for help but none of the other nobles decided to intervene.

Well, this was a legacy nipped in the bud Lance thought, ready to move on. There was not really anything he could do at this point since they were nobles and Lance was not willing to hang around to watch the poor mare being eaten alive. Camo stopped him from leaving though. "Lance, aren't we going to help her?"
1111111.title: A pony was being pulled on the table

choices: Run for the hills! Forget Camo!
Camo's there... and all eyes are on Lance. He has to go in there now.
1111112.content:
Lance saw those golden eyes fixed on him, staring right into his emerald orbs. Her many chins split with a wide, brilliant white smile. A hoof was raised and suddenly the gate before them squeaked open, the two burnished gold parts seperating, splitting the stylized "V" that declared this the Vorare estate. Lance knew he should move on, quickly run, but he was as stunned as Camo, the two rookie guards staring like bunnies at an oncoming train.

"If it isn't two members of our prestigious guard," Lady Vorare announced grandly, her voice carrying all the way out to them. A pair of large stallion in waistcoats trotted towards them, looking like some mixture of butler and bodyguard. They stopped before the gate, towering over the pair yet standing so aloofly they clearly thought nothing of Lance and Camo. "Please do come in, there's always a spot at my table for our judicious lawkeepers," the mare continued, directly extending an invitation.

Camo blinked twice and then grinned. "Sure!" he called as he began to trot forwards, the promise of cake no doubt too much for him to resist. A large hoof came down in front of him, stomping into the ground, and a sharp glare suddenly came from one of the towering stallions. Camo almost jumped out of his fur, but managed to swallow it down before looking over to the mare and bowing his head. "I would be honoured, Lady Vorare!" he corrected himself. The stallion lifted a hoof, and Camo was allowed to pass once more.

"Please, enjoy yourself, feast on our sweet treats, get yourself nice and plump," Lady Vorare called to him. Lance saw her lick her lips, and then her eyes settle on his again. "And you, private. Please, come and join the party, it's the least we can offer in return for our safety," she said, her eyes twinkling menacingly. Lance swallowed nervously, those two butlers towering over him... but the gate was still open.
1111112.title: A Late Invitation

11111121.content:
Forget that. A bit of cake and sweets wasn't worth dying over. These nobles had a reputation, and he didn't plan to be the one they used to live up to it.

Throwing his professionalism to the wind, he turned tail and ran. Immediately the stallions gave chase, but Lance was smaller and more agile. His armour didn't help, certainly, but although the stallions were imposing and clearly powerful, they would be hard pressed to catch him. Most importantly, if the stallions were in fact unicorns, his armour was (hopefully) resistant to magic.

Unfortunately, Lance had not planned out his escape as well as he should have. As he rounded a corner, he found himself running down an alley with a brick wall at the end. Glancing over his shoulder, he saw that the stallions had not turned the corner yet, so he needed to find somewhere to hide, or at least some way to defend himself.

He stopped at the end of the alleyway, looking around. This being the noble quarter, even the alley was fairly clean, but there was a large dumpster nearby that would make a decent hiding place. There was also a rusty lead pipe lying beside it, though it was hard to say if it would do anything against his pursuers. Whatever he chose, he needed to do it fast.
11111121.title: Run for the hills! Forget Camo!

111111211.content:
Lance knew how to fight. Being in the royal guard, it would be pretty embarassing if he didn't. However, fighting at a disadvantage would be a very bad idea and only get him killed so hiding was a better option. Even though he worked quickly, Lance still made sure not to be too loud as he dove into the stinking garbage bin. His nose was immediately assaulted by the stench of junk. Somehow he hoped that, if the stallions found him, Lady Vorare would no longer consider him as potential meal. Going back to the barracks alone and in dire need of the showers was still better than showing up in the toilet of some fatass noble.

From outside he heard the hoofsteps of his followers. Lance did not dare to move a muscle, on the threat of alerting his pursuers. In this situation, the anger at Camo was rising within Lance. How did this dumbass make it to the guard? No matter, he gets what's coming to him for being so oblivious once he's gurgling away. Lance's ears perked up as he heard the voice of one of the stallions right next to his hiding spot.
111111211.title: Hide in the dumpster.

1111112112.content:
“Probably teleported over the wall,” one of the stallions grunted loudly. Lance tried not to make a noise as he endured the stinking trash inside the dumpster, even when the metal squealed as one of the stallions no doubt sat back on it.

“So what do we do?” the other stallion asked.

“Well, he’s gone. I guess we’ll have to find her another meal… but first I’ve really got to take a shit,” the first stallion replied.

A snort of laughter came from the other stallion. “Read my mind. You want to share the dumpster? No point making a mess on the floor.”

Lance’s eyes went wide as he heard that. Surely they couldn’t… surely they wouldn’t…. “Give a seat at least,” the other stallion replied.

The dumpster lid squealed as it opened up, Lance expecting to see one of them staring down at him. What he saw was worse. Two massive, muscled flanks covered up the whole dumpster. Lance tried to scream when a pair of horrendous, wretched farts filled his lungs, the stallion’s breath stolen by the nastiest of stinks. Lewd grunts came from both massive stallions as gassy blast after eggy cloud ripped out and into the dumpster, the trash smelling like fresh cut grass by comparison to the horrendous butt stink.

A thick log of stinking brown began to slide from the cheeks right above Lance’s head… and the guardspony desperately tried to move, but he’d gotten his legs wedged in the trash. “No...no…” he managed to gasp as he saw the log stretching, an equine hoof and various scraps of coloured fur embedded in the log… then it broke. With a wet thump it splatted onto Lance’s face.

“Ugh… those parties are always fun, but damn do live meals give me messy shits,” one of the bodyguards grunted as thick buttsfudge squeezed out of his cheeks, the thick and solid mass squeezing out and slamming down with a splat over Lance’s hindlegs, everything below his waist being buried in the mess.

Desperately thrashing, Lance managed to free his muzzle, and then his face… just in time to see a skull staring down at him… and the massive compact loaf of shit behind it. “Noooo!” Lance squealed before it dropped with a horrendous squelch.

“Huh, you hear something?” one of the guards asked the other.

“Like what?” the other replied, shaking his ass to help squeeze out a long line of mushy crap as a loosely held together coil, unknowingly spreading it all over the struggling guardpony’s chest.

“I dunno… just thought I did,” the first said with a shrug, before grunting and letting another solid slab of shitty brown and then a sigh. “Well I’m done.”
The other big stallion finished up with a last grunt, and a final thud of shit. “Let’s go find the Lady a meal then.”

“Maybe we’ll find the guard while we’re at it. We’ve still got a lesson to teach him,” the first stallion replied with a laugh and the pair of them trotted away.

The dumpster was left wide open, stuffed full of messy, filthy shit. The only part of Lance still visible was a white hoof that twitched and wriggled, the rest of him utterly buried under pounds of pony shit. The wriggling soon became more frantic, and then went still, the hoof going limp… Maybe being captured would have been better.
1111112112.title: Hiding TOO Well

choices: The Hedge Maze. Just don't enter...
Lance knows the flower fields pretty well so they're a good bet.
The exotic greenhouses, that's the place ponies might actually need busting.
11112.content:
Straining his ears Lance could make out the sounds of something going on at the Estate. Music bled through the air and the sounds of refined joviality could only mean one thing... and that was to stay away. "Let's head out to the left. Gardens are most beautiful in the morning," Lance stated, gesturing with his head in the stated direction.

Camo's response was a simple shrug. As soon as Lance started trotting, so too did Camo, the stallion sticking to Lance's side. Their golden armour reflected the light of the sun as they trotted side by side down the paved street. "So you been to the gardens before?" Camo asked.

Lance had been liking the silence, but gave a sidewards glance with an emerald eye as Camo opened his muzzle. "Once or twice... though only to the publicly available part. There's a large field of flowers that is popular for picnics and other outdoors activities. We're being tasked to patrol the whole grounds though, give them a one over for any signs of ponies where they shouldn't be," Lance explained as the pair's hooves clipped and clopped against the ground.

A spiked and tall fence of golden metal came into view soon enough, marking the edge of the park and breaking up the endless rows of fancy townhouses. A bit further along lay the large and impressive gate, it wide open for public entry. Golden letters stenciled above proudly proclaimed this was indeed the one and only 'Faust Memorial Gardens'. "How about you?" Lance asked, turning to Camo. "First time here?" Camo nodded his head with an affirmative, and Lance grinned. "Then follow me."

Beyond the gate a smoothed out gravel path led the way forwards, and almost instantly the grass gave way to a sea of flowers. All kinds of brilliant and vibrant colours created a mesmerising rainbow of floral decoration, the plants put down in clear grids of solid colour blocks. Between each a marble statue of an alicorn was placed, all the way down to a central plaza, where an even grander statue of shaped gold tried to capture the glory of the supposed mother of equinity. Camo let out a loud whistle as he approached. "That can't have been cheap..." he stated, his vision filled by the golden statue.

Lance rolled his eyes as Camo acted like a colt. The plaza had a few ponies around, though none seemed to be the type of noble they were trying to avoid. Beneath the statue was unbroken grass, and beyond that stretched the large and famous field of flowers that went on for a mile at least. Several wooden benches provided places to sit, some also featuring tables for the picnickers.

Camo spotted the sign first and trotted over to it, stopping in front and looking up. "So all these places need to be patrolled?" Camo asked, looking back to Lance.

The other guardstallion trotted over to quickly double check and then gave Camo a nod. "Yep. We've got the exotic flora greenhouses, most of them off limits to any but staff or researchers from the Canterlot Academy. Those are to the East. On the West side we've got the largest hedge maze in Equestria... though we probably don't have to actually enter it. And of course up ahead is the sea of flowers. Question though is which to hit first...?"
11112.title: The Sometimes Gardener

choices: Get a drink. It's going to be a long day.
Suspicious activity already! Lance should investigate!
1112.content:
The Market District was a pretty popular pic, it being the most patrolled area of the city on a business day like today. Lance and Camo easily joined one of the larger groups, eight rookies trotting side by side out of the barracks and to the district. Wanting to be in the centre of the action, Lance had picked a place right out in the main plaza, and when they arrived he quickly began to reconsider his choice.

The Plaza was massive, a sea of colourful fabric on wooden stilts as a veritable sea of market stalls selling everything and anything filled the place. The yell of merchants advertising their wares made it hard to hear, and just below their volume was the endless drone of thousands of ponies chatting at once. Mares and stallions of all ages and sizes passed from stall to stall, buying whatever they wanted. How were you supposed to spot a criminal in this?

"Wow... market day is busy," Camo said, earning multiple glares for his all too obvious statement.

"We should fan out but stick to our pairs," a green unicorn mare stated, earning nods from the others. "Anypony shouts for help and we all come running."

"Sounds good to me," Lance replied, before spotting a nice shaded spot where the crowd weren't trotting. "Camo and I'll set up over there," he added, giving the mare a nod before gesturing for Camo to follow. The two stallions trotted away, the group soon disintegrating into four pairs that all spread out to cover just this quadrant of the massive marketplace.

It wasn't easy going just getting to the spot as the two guardsponies had to elbow through a few ponies, muscle their way through the crowd. More than once it had seemed like Lance was about to be crushed between two mares, but he squeezed past just in the nick of time. The two were panting when they arrived, marking out their location to start.

"Hey, can we get a drink?" Camo asked, looking at one of the nearby stalls.

Lance gave a shrug. "Well I guess we can..." he said, his eyes wandering. It was then he noticed the striped flank of a zebra disappearing into a side alley. His eyes narrowed, and just behind trotted a unicorn stallion with a very suspicious trot.
1112.title: Market Day

choices: A look of appeal wins him over.
A withering glare drives him away.
11122.content:
Lance gave Camo a nudge, catching the pudgy colt in the chest. "Hey, you see that?" he stated, gis hoof outstretching to point like an arrow at the suspicious looking unicorn. Was he carrying a briefcase? And wearing a fedora? Were criminals really that obvious? If things were this easy, then how did the guard lose so many eager recruits? Lance shook his head, and then looked over to Camo who was openly staring right at the figure before it vanished.

"Yeah... yeah, okay, I think even a newborn would find that suspicious..." Camo said, a visible frown on his muzzle. "If anything it's too suspicious... like, no criminal would do that so it has to just be a legitimate deal," he concluded, giving a shrug. "So can we get a drink now? I need something sugary or I think I'm going to pass out..."

Lance sighed, his eyes having long rolled. "There's no such thing as too suspicious, Camo. It's still suspicious, so I'm still checking it out. You coming with?" the unicorn asked, giving the pudgy earth pony a definite look.
11122.title: Detective Pointed Lance

choices: Confront the pair now while they're still there!
111222.content:
"Fine, if you're going to be like that, then you go and play detective all you want. I'm going to get a drink, then start patrolling," Camo replied with a slight growl. The earth pony then stuck his tongue out foalishly and trotted away, breaking the first rule of the buddy system and leaving Lance quite alone.

"I don't need you anyway!" Lance called after him, before turning and shaking his head. He'd just get him caught. Lance could shut down whatever deal was going on by himself, and then they'd make him a captain or something. If they resisted then all he had to do was call for help, and he was sure backup would be just around the corner. The white unicorn straightened his armour, then raised his middle to stand tall. "We'll see what Accipiter thinks of this," he stated with a grin.

The alleyway led off of the main street, but like all the worst alleys there was a nice big bend in the middle, only a small one to get around a building but enough that there was a small stretch that couldn't be seen from either side. Unfortunate for Lance as it meant he had to get right up close. He briefly pressed his back to the side of the wall next to the alley to check down it, earning a few looks from passing ponies trotting about enjoying market day. The coast was clear, smelly and dirty, but quite clear. The unicorn circled around and pushed himself to enter.

The grungy floor kept trying to tug his hoofcups from his hooves, forcing him to curl them as best he could with each step as he tried and failed a silent step. Fortunately there really was no guard positioned out there. Sure, he had only seen two individuals, but that didn't mean there couldn't be more. As he got close to the bend, passing a filthy dumpster that positively oozed a slime comprised of junk, his ears flicked at the sound of voices.

121111.content:
“My ancestors have been both friends and foes to the griffon race,” Moon said confidently. “I’ve been taught to understand their ways from birth. Gathering intel on them should be a piece of fruitcake for me.”

Nox smiled at her brashness. “The case is yours then. Well, half of it is. Remember, cadets are first supposed to learn patrolling, then how to take down griffon mafia. I’ve already assigned an investigator for this operation: Corporal Silhouette. You shall meet her tonight in the tavern of Silver Horse, and your main task is to offer whatever help you can to her. Understood?”

“Yessir,” said Moon, albeit less boldly than before. For a moment she had thought she’d get to lead an investigation on her own – not just work as someone’s sidekick. In any case, that was the case she had chosen, and it was what she’d stick with.

A couple hours from the briefing, when the evening started stretching its limbs over the streets of Canterlot, Moonbounce headed towards the Silver Horse. From outside it appeared like any other tavern in Canterlot, which wasn’t to say much. Ins such as the Horse were turning scarce in the magical city, being replaced by fashionable cafés and restaurants. A sense of nostalgia wafted from the place into Moon’s nostrils as she stood at the door. Correcting her uniform one more time, she stepped in.

The faint music that had spilled outside turned out to come from a piano in the corner, played by an aged stallion more or less admiringly. Long, measuring looks greeted Moonbounce on pace with the slow melody. For a moment it seemed like the whole room was inhaling her presence, tasting her like fine smoke, then returning back where it had left with an exhale that left her feeling less than welcomed. Nonetheless, she ordered a drink (a water with ice) and sat down at one of the empty, round tables like everyone else, waiting for her contact to appear.

She could not help noticing that a larger than average portion of the customers here were griffons. This had to be some sort of a haunt for the small avian minority that inhabited the Cliffs of Canterlot. Even the bartender was a griffon – the first of her kind Moon had seen.

Suddenly, somepony sat opposite to her. “Cadet Moonbounce?” asked the slim-built, sea-green pegasus mare dressed in Lunar Guard’s uniform.

“Uh, yeah, that’s me,” said Moon, not quite sure if she should salute or not. “Uhm… Corporal Silhouette?”

“Aren’t we on duty?” she managed when the bottle hit the table.

“Do me a favour, cadet,” burped Silhouette, wiping foam from her jaw. “Stop being green. Right now. This side of town, green is what the bottoms of cobblestones are made of.”

I got no time to give you a soft landing: a case I’ve been working on for months is about to solve itself. This night, everything has to go perfectly. You understand me?”

Moon nodded quickly. “Is that the case of sm–”

Silhouette’s wing zapped to hush her. “Not here, imbecile. Come, pay the bill. We’ve got to hurry.”

She really should pay her own drinks at least, thought Moon as they set off on the streets. There was no doubt that the corporal was a bully, but if she could really teach her something important, Moon was ready to suck up the barks. For this one night, at least.

“What did they tell you about the smugglers?” asked Silhouette while they trotted from one beam of streetlight to the next.

“Not much, really,” confessed Moon. “It was just Sergeant Nox’s hunch. He said griffon gangs were under suspicion for several crimes, including assaults, theft and trashing. For painting graffitis,” she specified when the corporal raised an eyebrow at the last crime. She snorted.

“Figures. Do they even read the reports I send them?”

“What do you mean?”

“I mean the griffons have nothing to do with anything resembling a crime in these parts,” said Silhouette. “I’ve been tracking a whole different lead; a real whammy, mind you.”

“Oh,” said Moon. “Odd. Sergeant Nox seemed so sure that–”

“Between you and me,” said Silhouette, glancing at Moon, “Sergeant Nox would suspect a griffon if an ice cream disappeared in a desert. Not his favourite race, you see.”

Moon frowned. “You’re saying he’s… biased?”

“Not that thick after all, are you. There’s a story buried there, you can bet on that. Behave and maybe I’ll let you in on it one of these nights,” Silhouette said, smirking at her.

“Okay,” said Moon. “So, what’s the whammy?”

“Dogs,” drawled Silhouette. “Diamond dogs.”

“What? I didn’t even know there were diamond dogs in Canterlot, much less criminal ones.”

“About time you learned then,” continued the corporal. “Officially there aren’t any, that’s true. But unofficially, the mountain’s loaded with tunnels filled with the creepers. I’ve been shadowing their activities for a long while now, trying to keep a lid on this thing. It’s huge, you see. They’re smuggling all sorts of stuff for pretty much anypony who can afford them, from arcane items to slaves.”

“Slaves?” gasped Moon. “There are slaves in Canterlot?”

“It’s a dark world under the mountain,” said Silhouette grimly. “Not something they tell in the tourist brochures. Not good advertisement, you see.”

You’ll help expose one of the biggest crime rings of Equestria, right on your first night on duty. Aren’t you proud?”

“But, but,” started Moon. “What happens to me after you’ve… sold me?”

1211111121.title: Submit

1211111122.content:
“Stop!” she yelped as the belt was about to touch her chin. “Just stop, okay? Hold on a second.”

“Meat speaks,” observed the dog. The casualness of the comment had something very terrifying about it.

“I’m no one’s meat! I’m your slave!” snapped Moon hysterically. “You’re not supposed to eat slaves!” she added when the looks she got remained uncaring.

“Meat’s loud,” said the dog. The belt wrapped around her muzzle.

“I’m a guardspony!” cried Moon, yanking her head free from the noose.

This at least incited a reaction. The dog who had went to the fireplace stopped digging, and the two others looked at him. Moonbounce prayed she hadn’t botched everything, including her chances of survival.

“A guard…?” said the leader dog, turning slowly to Moon. The yellow eyes drilled into her viciously.

“I am,” she said carefully. The cat was out of the bag; she might as well let it out the door too. “Cadet Moonbounce, Lunar Guard, second division.”

“A guard,” growled the dog. His paws squeezed into fists. “Fellas, we’ve been tricked.”

“What’s ya mean, Berg?” asked the dog who had been about to muzzle Moonbounce.

“The bloody feather brains!” shouted Berg. He grunted at the questioning looks of his friends. “You don’t see? The griffons sold us out. There’s a bunch of soldiers marching here right now, about to capture us with one of their own.”

“Wait, what?” asked Moon. “The griffons?”

“By my fleas, you’re right,” said a dog. “It’s a trap!”

“What do we do? What do we do?”

“What did you mean, the griffons sold you out?”

“Shut up!” barked Berg. “Shut the bat up! I needs to think…”

“Hey, wait!” Moonbounce tried as the dogs grabbed her again. This time they didn’t stop at her pleads, but secured her tightly and muzzled her mouth shut so hard her teeth ached. Wordlessly she watched as the dogs withdrew to argue. Meanwhile, another battle took place inside her head. How were the griffons involved in this? Did the dogs think corporal Silhouette worked for them? Had she infiltrated into their camp too? But she had said the griffons were not a factor… None of this made sense to Moonbounce.

What did made sense, horrible such, was the smell of cooked meat wafting from the spot Berg had been digging. If she strained her neck, she could just about see half a leg sticking out from the ashes.

She flinched as the dogs suddenly stood around her. That was the last thing she saw before she was stuffed into a sack and lifted up, to be carried into the night. From the little information she could gather she deduced they headed back to the city, deep into its heart. After hours, the sound of paws on cobblestones finally stopped. Shattering glass signaled a broken window. They entered a building of some sort, the characterizing smell of which was… cream?

“Hoist her there,” she heard said. She felt as she was carried up, possibly via ladders. Her cramped, painful and suffocating situation finally ended when the sack’s mouth was opened. She stretched out her neck, desperate for air and information about her surroundings.

It looked like a factory, but not what she imagined a factory should look like, if that made any sense. Steel and ceramic tiles dominated the site. Strange machines shone in the moonlight spilling through the large windows. She hang over a huge metal vat filled with some pale, bleak liquid. Cream, Moonbounce realized.

“Okay, drop her,” said Berg from down below.

Moonbounce whimpered as her sack was emptied into the vat. The fall ended with a mighty splash. The cream was shallow enough to let her hit the bottom hard yet deep enough to electrify her with the fear of drowning. She struggled to keep her head afloat, the white, thick substance matting her fur all over. She looked up, but the dog had already disappeared. What were they planning to do with her?

Somewhere around her, wheels started turning. The dogs were operating the machines, bringing the factory to life. Moonbounce felt lost and panicked in equal measure. The cream seeped in past her closed lips, overwhelming her with the taste of sugar, fat and spices. Somewhere very near, a loud humming noise intensified.

“That should do it,” said the distorted voice of Berg from beyond the metal wall. “Problem solved. They’ll find her in the morning, far from our den, got with nothing to do with us. Still, we better start thinking of changing the city. This one’s getting too small for us and the chickens.”

“Can’t we stay to see how she turns out?” asked another voice. It was met with an angry growl. Beyond that, Moonbounce was left alone with the humming. She floundered in the cream for her life. It stretched her imagination to think of a worse situation.

Time passed, and Moonbounce kept involuntarily swallowing countless gulps of cream. Perhaps she could drink her way out of this. Perhaps she would not need to. For some reason, the white pond around her was turning less liquid by the minute. At first she thought she was turning it into whip cream with her thrashing, but then another realization struck her: it was getting increasingly cold. Warmth fled the vat as if driven away by the incessant mechanical humming. She was shivering now. And the cream only kept turning more freezing, stiffening until it almost resembled… ice cream.

When the morning came, Moonbounce wasn’t shivering anymore. She barely breathed. Thin slices of air moved back and forth her ice-blue lips half immersed in ice cream. The engines had purred all night, solidifying the cream and almost turning Moon into a living snowbat. She couldn’t feel anything anymore. In fact, when the humming finally stopped, she was actually starting to feel a bit hot. It was the last phase of hypothermia knocking on the door of her life. I have to get out of here, she thought.

Outside the vat, the first early bird worker had turned up, noticed somepony had left the machines on for the night, thus readying this batch for further processing. Whistling to herself, she pushed a few levers and released the hydraulic press on the ice cream, which would be pushed out of the hole in the bottom and under the conveyor belt below, on which empty packages already awaited to be filled with the delicious treat.

About to carry on with other tasks, the worker suddenly halted when the press began complaining. Gears grinded one another, clearly encountering unexpected resistance. She looked at the vat, wondering what hindered the compression. The pressure increased dangerously; already she could hear the boiler whining. This time its screaming sounded even more equine than usual. She was about to stop the engine when the high-pitched noise ceased, at the same moment when something gave inside the vat with a crunch.

Soon enough, ice cream started flowing through the funnel as intended. There was something off about the color though. The worker walked to the conveyor belt and scooped a hoofful of the pinkish sorbet. Mindful that nopony saw her, she gave it a lick. Funny, she thought. This batch was supposed to be plain vanilla, but she detected a hint of apple.

12111112.title: "I'm out"

1211112.content:
“If being green means the same as following the Guard’s code of conduct, you can call me lush all night long,” said Moonbounce dryly.

The corporal stared at her like a gravestone for full five seconds, then burst out laughing. Moonbounce could feel the prickling of angry eyeballs on her skin. Silhouette didn’t seem to mind the attention at all, for her cackle seesawed into giggling during a span of several minutes.

“Good one, Moony,” she finally said, wiping tears off her cheeks. “You’ve really made my night.”

“If only I could say the same,” replied Moonbounce, yanking up her collar to cover her blush.

SIlhouette took note of that over her raised drink. “Bah, never mind these knuckleheads. Let them think what they will. This place could use some mirth, I always say.”

Over the table and through the faint cigarette smoke, Moonbounce glared at the pegasus who was supposed to be her superior; somepony she was supposed to look up to and learn from. All she could see was a loudmouth jerk with a possible drinking problem. The quicker she could depart from her company, the better.

“I understood you had a case in your hooves,” said Moon.

“Damn right I do,” replied Silhouette after finishing her cider. She leaned conspiratorially forward. “It’s called ‘another round’. You up for it, Moony?”

“Stop calling me that,” growled Moonbounce under her breath. “And you can’t be serious: we’re supposed to be solving crimes, not drinking our asses off in a lousy bar!”

That last part came across louder than she had intended. The eyeballs crept up her neck along with the red of embarrassment.

“Suit yourself,” retorted Silhouette. She stood up. “Make yourself useful and hold onto the table: I have a call of nature to answer to. And order the drink too. That’s an order.”

Now the flaming on Moon’s face wasn’t all due to shame. If looks could kill, the corporal would’ve been blown to bits as she swaggered towards the toilets. I swear, Sergeant Nox will get a report the likes of which he hasn’t seen since the Great Betrayal of 716, she swore.

As Moonbounce was about to order another cider (since orders are orders), she noticed how, right after Silhouette had disappeared into the mare’s room, a griffon sitting in the nearby table got up and followed her. Ordinary as the observation was, there was still something about that which tickled her suspicion. Perhaps she too should pay a quick visit to the lavatory. On the other hoof, that would mean running into corporal Silhouette possibly several minutes earlier than was necessary.
1211112.title: Stand firm

12111121.content:
It was probably nothing, reasoned Moonbounce. In any case, nothing so important that she would bother eavesdropping the corporal taking a leak, break wind or both.

After a blissfully long while, Silhouette finally returned from the restroom. Moon expected her to seat and uncork the fresh cider, but instead the pegasus, after dropping a few bits on the counter, tacitly gestured her to exit the bar. The prospect of getting some action relieved Moon enough so that she didn’t even bother wondering why the previously laid-back mare would so eagerly abandon her drink.

“Where we’re going?” Moon asked as they stepped outside.

“To the barracks,” said Silhouette. The green-blue mare set off to fly down the street with Moonbounce behind her.

“Why?”

“Because I says so,” snapped Silhouette without looking at her. Moon used the opportunity to stick out her tongue at her rump. The corporal seemed a lot tenser than a moment ago, but apparently her manners were coarse regardless of her mood. That report will be a joy to write, assured Moonbounce herself.

They flew across the city without exchanging words or looks. The route they took wasn’t what Moon would’ve chosen, which made her consider the option the corporal wasn’t only unruly but incompetent too. But as they halted in the middle of a construction yard, Moonbounce became convinced her partner was neither of those things – she was simply mad.

“Shoot,” said Silhouette, landing. “I forgot my drink back there. Gotta fetch it before they steal it.” She turned to Moon and said, with emphasis, “Stay here. Stay right here. Got it? Right here.”

“You’re kidding me,” gasped Moonbounce. “You’re flying back for a bloody drink? In the middle of our shift?”

“Hey, who's the corporal here?” demanded Silhouette, pointing at the solitary stripes on her shoulders. “You’ll do as you’re told or you’ll fly out of the Guard sooner than I can get that cider! Now wait here, right here, until I get back.”

With that she was gone and Moon ready to seriously reconsider her career choice. A devoted and eager guard that she was, a night paired with corporal Silhouette tested her loyalty more than facing a changeling army alone ever could. The bugs at least had the decency to kill you quickly.

Seething in anger, Moon nonetheless grew bored. There was not much to look around. The fenced area they had been crossing harbored the makings of a new library. Mighty pillars supporting a half-finished roof loomed next to her, the lone ropes used to haul huge rocks into the heights blowing in the faint wind. Moonbounce sighed. Above her, something creaked. The wind swooshed a tad stronger. She looked up. She screamed.

A few moments later, corporal Silhouette landed on the spot which Moonbounce had very recently occupied, but which now contained nothing but a massive chunk of marble. It stood there in silence comparable in intensity only to the brief shriek and loud crunch that had preceded it. The pegasus walked around the rock a couple of times, looking for any signs of success, which she for her worry could not find. The rim of the boulder was spotless, betraying neither a hair nor a drop of blood, although in the darkness it was hard to be sure. That she had to be.

With a crowbar, jack and a lot of sweat Silhouette managed to lift one side of the slab enough to get a look underneath. Despite the gruesome sight and a sickening squelch of tissue breaking free, a satisfied smile spread on her lips. The crane had been difficult to align, but she had hit the bullseye on the first go. Oh yes.

The ground under Moonbounce had sank an inch under her figure rammed flat by the impact. The mare’s flanks had burst from both sides, and mushed entrails spilled from among several broken ribs. The ruptured spine pierced skin at several places. Mangled wings sprang up as the rock departed them, protruding into unnatural directions. The batpony’s four legs had survived the best, the meaty thighs excluded, although that wasn’t much of a compliment. The reasonably well-toned muscles were but minced meat now. The overall impression was of a bloated water ball thrown at a brick wall.

What surprised Silhouette was how well the head of the thestral had been preserved. An indentation almost as big at the bottom of the marble had preserved it, if not unharmed, then at least relatively whole. The mare’s muzzle ended in a bleeding stump now, but one could still clearly make out the petrified expression stuck on her face; hear the last note of her wail sprouting from the wide open mouth. Thick streams of blood trailed from her ears and eyes, and if Silhouette wasn’t completely wrong, the pony’s heart had somehow actually jumped up to her throat, clogging her gullet at the last seconds of her life.

Well, that was the easy part, thought Silhouette as she let the rock fall with a wet smack. The hard part, she knew, was to feign tears when she’d alarm the Guard of the unfortunate end of cadet Moonbounce.
12111121.title: Stay put

12111122.content:
If there was but a shadow of a chance of catching the corporal engaged in something illicit, Moonbounce would be all over it. She got up and headed towards the toilets.

The room was bigger than she had expected. Five stalls lined one wall, the opposite of which had a score of sinks and a few mirrors. Dirt was less of an issue than she had unconsciously presumed it would be. It appeared as if someone actually cleaned here once a year or so.

The biggest surprise, however, was that there was no one else around. Where had they gone? After a shy peek into a couple of the stalls, Moonbounce got her answer. At the back of the room, behind the last stall, there was backdoor. It was narrowed open, and the cool air that seeped in told her it lead outside. In the backyard, somepony was talking. Moonbounce pressed herself against the frame to listen.

“–don’t need to tell me that,” said corporal Silhouette’s voice. “I got this, as always. But not like I originally planned.”

“If not with the dogs, how then?” said another voice, which Moon presumed was the griffon’s. A hint of unmistakable self-sufficiency salted with avian accent left little room for doubt.

“I’m working on it,” said Silhouette defensively. “She’s tougher than I anticipated a cadet to be. Maybe smarter too. It’s no use feeding her a story she won’t bite.”

“Snuff her out here?”

“No!” said Silhouette. “That’s the worst idea. Or do you want the Guard come sniffing? They're already suspicious about the Horse, I told you. We got to be more… subtle about this.”

The griffon grumbled something, but Moon’s mind already raced the other way. It did not take a paranoid to figure out they were talking about her – about “snuffing her out”. The shock of the news traversed Moon like a lightning, splitting her brain in half. The first part wanted her to take wing and flee the place ASAP. The other wished the exact the contrary: to know why they planned getting rid of her, and how she could perhaps counter the hospitality in kind.
12111122.title: Go have a look
