It wasn't as if she didn’t have reason enough to bolt without the prospect of being murdered by her supposed partner. She would get the hell out here and give her report to Sergeant Nox sooner than intended.

Her heart bouncing, Moonbounce backed away from the door. Mindful to avoid making noise, she dared to turn around only at the exit, through which she surged as if on fire. As a consequence, she bumped head-on to the griffon moving the opposite direction.

“Sorry,” said Moonbounce hastily, trying to squeeze through the bulk of the creature. Griffons as a rule outweighed ponies, but this one dwarfed most carts, too. “Uh, excuse me, I really need to get through…”

“Where’s the rush, little pony?” asked the griffon. He stepped forward, pushing Moonbounce back into the restroom.

“None of your business,” she retorted, desperately trying to circle the hindrance. As unlikely as it seemed, the resistance the griffon posed wasn’t all passive in nature.

“Big words,” the avian-feline commented casually. A clawed hand that could cover most of Moonbounce’s face settled on her shoulder. It stayed there, and so did the rest of Moon.

“W-what’s this?” she said.

“A surprise,” said a familiar voice behind her. Colour fled Moon’s face as she looked around.

“I saw her creeping in after you,” commented the big griffon at Silhouette and the other bird who had returned from the backyard. “Think she overheard you.”

“I didn’t!” yelped Moonbounce, way too quickly. “I mean, I didn’t hear anything I’d remember, okay? In fact, I heard so little I could move out of the city tomor–tonight!”

“I can keep her, right?” said the griffon holding Moon’s shoulder. The hopefulness in his voice made her neck hair rise.

“Go ahead, Falke,” said the other griffon. “Just be quick about it.”

“Aww, where’s the fun in that?” complained Falke.

Moonbounce tried to voice an objection, which Falke’s massive talon over her mouth stunted. She looked pleadingly at Silhouette, who only shook her head slowly.

“I told you to stay still, Moony. Not that it would’ve saved you, but at least I would’ve made sure your passing would be quick and clean. As is, well… At least this place can’t possibly get any messier, so there’s that.”

Moonbounce followed in growing fright as she was left alone with Falke. The door’s lock clicked after its closure, ensuring no one would come bothering them. Panicking, she was about to try and wrench free, but the feeling of the griffon’s beak sliding along her neck eliminated the option. One wrong move and she’d be sliced open like a fish. She jumped as Falke inhaled her fur.

“Hmm, like fresh apples,” he commented after the long and extremely intrusive sniff. “Won’t be that fresh for long.”

Before Moon could hypothesize the meaning of the remark, she got picked up like a doll and smashed through one of the stall doors. With both of his hands clenching her shoulders, she could finally scream, for the whole three seconds it took for him to ram her headfirst into the toilet seat. Slimy, murky water gushed out while she dived deep into the filthy drain. The bare shock of it triggered an instant fit, which she jerked through while Falke rinsed the grimy pipe with her face.

Right before she was about to drown the griffon pulled her back, allowing her lungs fill with the precious, stale air instead of the toilet’s contents. Her matted mane glued over her eyes, preventing her from seeing how Falke hurled her out and against one of the sinks, under which she slumped. Body convulsing in grips of wet coughs, Moonbounce couldn’t summon any resistance as the griffon walked to her, grabbed a tuft of her hair and yanked her head up.

“Not as good as olive oil, but that’ll do for lubrication,” he said while lifting a hind leg over the sink. “Bon voyage, bat-bitch.”

The last distinguishable sentence Moonbounce could muster, starting with “Please” and ending with “No”, was smothered by the griffon’s anus. The pale ring of elastic, wrinkled flesh stretched with unexpected ease around Moon’s moist muzzle, welcoming her with a warm, humid embrace. The easy ride stopped as the wiry gluteal muscles clenched her jaw so tight her teeth ached. Held still by the butt and Falke’s hand on her neck, Moon could but stare at the furry rear of the griffon into which she’d soon be forced.

“Yeah, keep doing that,” groaned Falke while she fiercely tried to unclench herself. “Make sure to wriggle all the way, cunt. Otherwise I’ll have to make you.”

Moonbounce couldn’t care less what the griffon might do, for the worst was already happening. As the muscles relaxed, a window opened for her to automatically draw breath. It almost killed her on the spot. The wind coming from the griffon’s bowels was the most hideous mix of rancid, rotten, fermented air there was. It made her fur fall of. It also stung her eyes, which now squeezed past the fleshy brim regardless of how much she fought back. A few grunts and shoves later her whole head had vanished between the bulging cheeks.

With the mare firmly stuck, Falke could afford to rest a moment. He let his raised leg hit the floor, shook his shoulders taxed by the labour of the day. Looking behind, she saw the pony pressing her legs against his back, vainly trying to pop her head free. He didn’t even need to tense anything to desist that. Lack of oxygen was plug enough for her efforts. It was the signal that some more should be allowed in, along with the main course of course.

The rank stench combined with the strangling pressure were about to overwhelm Moonbounce when her fleshy prison shifted again. The rim of the anus gaped open, feeding in her neck and spilling out her sorry scream infused with a fart. With fresh vigour she made another attempt to escape her unbearable destiny – to no avail. The griffon simply sat down, and Moonbounce was rammed up his ass all the way to her shoulders. The muscles tightened again, repeating the process, only with more intensity. Gasping, suffocating and crying, Moonbounce shrunk beyond the last glimmer of reason.

Falke’s tongue lolled out at the unbelievable sensation of fulfillment. The mare was just the right size to teasingly test his limits. Granted, some of it was due to the insufficiency of lubrication – he had taken in whole stallions before, properly oiled. The friction remained manageable, although the shoulders would demand a touch of duress. Preparing himself for the feat, Falke started stroking his already flaring erection.

The deeper she plunged, the more obnoxious the reek turned. Moonbouce swore her nasal hairs crisped already, and that her eyes would run liquid at the end of her journey. The stink had an almost material momentum; it seeped into her fur and beyond, burying into her insides by the rubs of the rectum. She wasn’t merely covered in filth and muck: she was changing into sludge with every inch of the way. I’ll be shit even before I get to the stomach, she thought in horror. The picture of herself as a brownish log travelling through the griffon’s intestines became interrupted by unimaginable pain of her shoulderplates grinding against her spine.

“Grrh, you are a thick one, aren’t you?” grumbled Falke, cramming Moon’s upper half up his butt. His strategy of quick back and forth rocking with his hips was working, but every inch of meat took a lot of persuading. Moreover, the flabby wings were more irritating that he would’ve thought. More leverage was required.

Every new wail of agony meant swallowing more gastric gas than she could stomach, but she could not resist her body’s natural reaction to being effectively crushed to death. Already she had disjointed a shoulder. Right now things had slowed down, a bend of a bowel staying her passage. She prayed, with whatever hope she had left, that it would be enough for the griffon to defecate her. She didn’t care if she’d be splattered all over the toilets like a bad diarrhea (with which she presently strongly identified) as long as it meant leaving this hell.

Enough of the mare had been incorporated for Falke to stand on all fours, which left the remaining bottom half of the pony dangling amusingly from his rear. She had grown quite still during the last push. He could feel she was still alive though; the movements of the moderate bulge in his abdomen testified to it. It was time to extract the last wriggles out of his prey before the ultimate climax. Drawing a couple lungfuls of strength, Falke dropped all his weight on the pony’s hind legs.

A mighty crunch echoed off of the ceramic tiles, followed immediately by a muffled shriek from deep within his intestines. That had taken care of her legs. The next buck crushed her pelvis, stirring an even shriller scream. The voice vibrated pleasantly within him. The pony’s parts sufficiently loosened, sucking them in with loud blorbs and squelches dotted the i’s and crossed the t’s of the griffon’s thrill. Via a broken mirror he followed the tips of Moon’s hooves getting suckled in his pucker hole, which sealed neatly after them, leaving but a few odd tail hairs hanging out. He pushed them in with a claw one by one, then lay down to study his spherical, quivering belly.

“Thanks for the ride, little pony,” he mused while prodding the lump with a claw, inciting the odd indistinct shout or a violent convulsion. “Enjoy your new home while it lasts. In a week or so you’ll be out for good, fertilizing the grass on which your kin likes to feed. Perhaps some of them will follow your lead. It’s the circle of nature right there. Adios.”

Giving himself one more pat, Falke stood up and wobbled to the bar’s side. Contrary to his customs he’d order an apple cider. It was the least he could do for the mare to offer her a drink, after all.
121111221.title: Flee

121111222.content:
It was at moments such as the present one in which a guard’s worth was weighed, and Moon considered herself no feather to be blown away willy-nilly by any random gust. She’d find out what exactly corporal Silhouette was planning, with whom and why. But before that she’d have to return back to her table, because it looked like the corporal and the griffon were about to finish up their scheming.

“Excuse me,” said Moon as she pushed through the restroom door and bumped into another griffon heading the other way. He gave her a long, measured look which she could not help but make a note of. There was no telling the extent of the corporal’s conspiracy, and until she’d get to the bottom of it, Moonbounce swore she’d trust no one save herself.

“You took your sweet time,” she said as Silhouette returned to the table.

“Shut it, cadet,” she retorted. Without seating, she nodded her to follow.

“What’s up?” she asked on the street.

“We’re heading back to the barracks,” said Silhouette. “There’s some… authorization issue I need to check before the night’s mission.”

“What sort of authorization?” queried Moon as they set off.

“Top secret. Come now, get a move on: we’re going to have our hooves full tonight.”

“Right,” said Moon slowly. For now she was content playing the part of the good, ignorant cadet. It was one facade against another, with the exception that Moon had spotted the corporal’s tapestry curling at the edges. The plain treason it hid became even more conspicuous as, without any apparent reason, they stopped at an empty construction yard.

“Oh, shoot,” said Silhouette, landing. “I forgot my drink back there. Gotta fetch it before the buggers nick it. You wait here: right here, until I get back. Shouldn’t take long.”

“As you say, corporal,” said Moon slowly. Silhouette raised an eyebrow, but glided away nonetheless. After she had disappeared, supposedly back where they had come from, Moon faced another decision – spy her again or hold still. Both options had their risks.
121111222.title: Play along

1211112221.content:
Like Moonbounce had suspected, Silhouette backtracked just long enough to give the illusion that she did. The next alley she made a u-turn and returned to the construction site, although this time from behind the building. After making it to the unfinished roof, Moonbounce followed her rummage around the edge, looking for something in the darkness below. It was then that she could not tolerate the suspense anymore.

“The last time I saw, the Silver Horse was on the roof of some other library.”

She could almost hear how Silhouette’s heart bounced up her throat. The pegasus spun around, wide eyes feverishly scanning the miscellaneous construction scenery. She only spotted Moonbounce as she stepped out of the deepest of the shadows, grinning with all her teeth.

“Bat got your tongue?”

“Very funny, cadet,” said Silhouette, recovering somewhat. “What the hell? I ordered you to stay down there!”

“Yeah, about that,” said Moon, casually stepping forward. “Why did you lie to me just then?”

“You got no right to–”

Moonbounce leapt. Silhouette, still clinging to the old script, hesitated a turn of breath too long. Moon toppled the lighter pegasus easily, and after a brief struggle ended it with her fangs on the jade-green throat.

“Go on,” Moon said. “Finish your sentence. Oh, and then you could explain just why you planned ‘snuffing me out’ with that griffon back in the Horse?”

The ensuing silence was all the confirmation Moon could’ve hoped for, and from Silhouette’s eventual reply she deduced the pegasus had arrived to a similar conclusion.

“I’m not saying jack.”

“So, that means you’re fine with me ripping your throat open?”

Silhouette snorted. “You wouldn’t. You’re just a cadet. How’d you explain that, killing your superior? The griffons won’t talk. That leaves you bluffing with no cards. Tell you what: get off of me now and we might come up with a deal that serves both of us.”

Moonbounce shifted uneasily. She hadn’t really considered things might come down to this. It was true, she was bluffing about the ripping of throat part – or so she had thought, up until she had been called out and left to choose between trusting a pony she knew wanted to end her and breaking the Guard’s code of conduct. She sighed mentally, then made up her mind.
1211112221.title: Spy

12111122211.content:
Wordlessly, Moonbounce retreated her teeth and backed away – far enough to keep her guard up, close enough to keep the corporal within her reach. She stood up and wiped dust off of her with an air of somepony who did this sort of stuff all the time.

“Say, how did you figure me out?” she said. “You eavesdropped us in the Horse, right?”

“I did,” conceded Moon. “But the warning had come earlier. Sergeant Nox is onto you. He instructed me to keep an eye on you.” The lie came to her out of the blue. It seemed wise to hoard some extra playing chips at her end.

“Really?” asked Silhouette slyly. “What’d he say, I wonder?”

“You said you had a deal on your mind,” said Moon coolly. “Spit it out here or in the barracks, it’s all the same to me.”

“Oh, aren’t we bold now,” teased Silhouette. “Think you can take me on twice in a row?”

“All night long if that’s what it takes. Now spill it out.”

For a moment Silhouette looked like she was considering the range of her life-options from a completely fresh angle. Whether this was truly the case or merely an elaborate ploy to play time, Moon could only guess.

“How much d’you know about the Beak Gang, exactly?”

“Enough,” said Moon, who had heard the name for the first time. “You’re working for them?”

“That’s one way to put it. More concretely I’m a slave to them – one of many, mind you.”

Moon frowned. “A slave?”

“They hold my friend a hostage,” said Silhouette, suddenly with tears in her once arrogant eyes. “Should I fail to do as they say…”

Now she was openly weeping. Moon felt at loss in the face of the novel turn of events. Her first inclination was towards disbelief. Nothing thus far had hinted the corporal was under coercion. On the other hoof, a threat on one’s friend’s life offered a plausible explanation of why a corporal of the Guard would turn her coat to begin with.

“How long has this been going on?”

“Almost a moon,” sobbed Silhouette. The last traces of aloofness peeled off her in slight trembles. The shimmering gaze turned to Moon. “I’m sorry for betraying you, Moon… But I had no choice! I didn’t know what to do! Please, have mercy on me…”

“Hey, hey,” said Moon. She approached the pegasus in undecidedly consolidating and/or cautious manner, which culminated in the hoof she laid on her shoulder both as a guard and comfort. “Hey, it’s okay. We can figure this out. What’s your friend’s name?”

“Silk Weaver,” sniffed Silhouette. “She used to work as a tailor.”

“I’m sure she shall in the future too,” assured Moon. She sighed deeply. “The best thing you can do for her is to come with me to Sergeant Nox and explain all this to him personally.”

“No!” cried Silhouette, jumping back. “No, I can’t! That’d be the end of Weaver. The griffons told me they have other guards in their pocket, but I don’t which ones. If one of them snitches on me…”

“You sure they’re not bluffing?”

“Of course not! But I can’t risk Weaver’s life like that! Do you think I haven’t gone over all the possible scenarios in my head a dozen times already? There is no way out from this. None except… No, that’s stupid. And dangerous.”

“What?”

Silhouette scraped the roof’s tiles nervously. “I… I know where they keep Weaver. They let me talk with her once a week. Tonight’s the time. With your help, we might be able to break her free.”

Moon gave her a deadpan expression. “Break into a mob lair? By the two of us? Are you serious?”

“I know I have no right to ask you that,” hurried Silhouette. “No right whatsoever. Only desperation. Please, I don’t know how long I can keep up the facade, or when they reason I’m becoming too much of a liability. It could already be too late! I think that after forcing me to get rid of you, it would’ve been my turn. I’m scared.”

Moon looked into the big, wet, green eyes and knew her heart had only one answer left in store for them.
12111122211.title: Release her

121111222111.content:
“I’m sorry to say this, but I’m not gonna risk my life in a suicide attempt for a pony who half an hour ago planned killing me,” said Moon. “You made your bed, now sleep in it.”

Silhouette stared at her in disbelief. “What… What then?”

“We go with the original plan: you come clean to Sergeant Nox. He’ll know what to do.” Moon spread her wings, about to take flight.

She was stopped by Silhouette who hurled herself around her neck, strangling with all her might.

“No! I won’t!”

“Let go off me!” wheezed the shocked Moon. The two mares flailed on the rooftop, wrestling for their lives, failing to notice the egde near which their uneven waltz took place. As one struggling ball of legs and wings, they fell, rolling over each other for the few velocious seconds the plummet took. Their combined screams ended abruptly at two sickening splats, like melons hitting a carpet of nails. In the end that was not that far from the truth.

It took Moon a moment to comprehend what had transpired. They had hit a concrete mold rife with solid steel rods awaiting to support the oncoming structure. Two had impaled her right leg, one had struck through her chest, probably puncturing a lung. Breathing had never been this painful. She coughed blood, blinked, and finally screamed. Inside her, fractured organs spread apart at the effort.

From the corner of her fading vision she saw Silhouette hadn’t faired any better. The mare had dived right into one of the bars, half of which now stuck from between her broken, bleeding teeth. An agonized gurgle fled her throat stiffened by the rod inside. She had turned into a living treat on a stick. The frightened eyes turned to Moon, sinking as her body weighed her down along the pole. One more gurgle and she fell silent, her protruding hind legs twitching randomly.

“Good riddance!” spat Moon with her waning strength. Blood trickled down the bars in earnest. She could not move a muscle without ten others hurting like hell. She was dying. Until, in due time, she wasn’t.
121111222111.title: Turn her down

121111222112.content:
“I can’t believe I’m saying this, but okay,” said Moon. “I assume you have some sort of a strategy in – whoah!”

“Thank you!” wailed Silhouette, who had tangled herself on Moon’s neck. “I’ll never forget this, I promise you!”

“That is sweet of you,” said Moon, pushing the clingy mare farther. “But I think you should save your thanks until we rescue Weaver, hmm?”

The pegasus gave her one more tight hug, then regained enough of her composure to stand on her own legs.

“Like I said, I’ve gone over all the scenarios in my head,” she said. “With you one of them might actually work. The Beaks hold headquarters in a warehouse not far from the Silver Horse. Weaver is being held inside. If you arrange a little distraction, I think I can manage to get her out.”

Moon nodded. “Let’s get to it then.”

“Are you sure this is the place?” she asked when they arrived at the warehouse. From outside it looked like any other magazine in the city which lived off of imported goods. No guards, no lights, not even a fence indicated anything exciting, much less criminal, was going on inside.

“It’s protected by cunning, not by power,” explained Silhouette. “There’s never too many griffons present at once – a dozen at most.”

A dozen criminal killing machines, each one packed with more muscle than we have between us, thought Moonbounce. Suddenly the idea of reinforcements seemed a lot more appealing, and she told Silhouette as much.

“Please,” begged the pegasus. “We’ve been over this. I could never forgive myself if something happened to Weaver. She’s already suffered so much for my sake.”

“I suppose you’re right,” sighed Moon. “But right after we’ve secured her safety, we’re marching to Nox with this.”

“Deal.”

The two mares descended on the looming building as per the plan, which boiled down to two decisive moments. Silhouette would get in the front door to give her report, giving Moon a window to slip in from one. While Silhouette would attract the attention of the guards with a wild tale, Weaver could be rescued. It all seemed simple enough. Almost too simple, thought Moon as she creaked one pane in the row of glass lining the top of the warehouse.

As Silhouette had revealed, it was dim inside. Griffons had better night vision than ponies – almost up to bat pony standards. Squinting, Moon could see a bunch of griffons gathering around the main entrance, where Silhouette waved them closer as agreed. On the other side of the large hall, beyond the mountains of crates, light burned from inside an office. That’s where Weaver would be. After checking the route was clear, Moon closed the pane carefully and glided by the wall until she could get a glimpse inside.

A certain unexpected relief washed over Moon at the sight of a tied, gagged pony laying in the corner. At the back of her mind the idea she was being played stopped whispering, albeit not grumbling. The pony was a thestral. Why hadn’t Silhouette mentioned it? Maybe she hadn’t thought it’d be important. In any case, there was also a guard in the room, idly tending to his claws with a file. It begged the question what else Silhouette had failed to mention.

Blame would have to wait for its due proceeding. The important thing now was to rescue the mare. As things stood, Moon could see but one way to it: she’d have to take the guard out. And because he was twice her size, she’d have no choice but to put her teeth into play. The Guard’s regulations had nothing good to say about exercising lethal force on citizens who hadn’t been read their rights before, but in the circumstances–

A clawed hand the size of a shovel grabbed her from behind and bowled her against the closest crate so hard she crashed right through. Inside she had precisely enough time not to black out before the box was ripped in two in one apparently effortless motion. The hand came at her again, picked her by the scruff of her neck like a puppy and raised her from among the splinters.

“Bloody gales,” rumbled the griffon who held her for inspection. “For once your slick tongue told the truth.”

“For you always, Wiff,” said Silhouette. She pushed her way past the griffons that now flocked to the site from all directions. They were all ogling at Moon, who hang helplessly like a fish from a hook. The obvious now dawned to her in all its naked horror.

“You lying filly of a–”

The griffon muzzled her with a grip that could bent steel. “Feisty still? How unexpected – and pleasing. The lively ones tend to have this spicy taste I adore.”

“Hmmphh?!” erupted Moon. Suddenly she became highly alert of the starving stares the griffons were throwing her way. One of them actually licked their beak.

“Tough luck, sweetheart,” giggled Silhouette. “Seems like we arrived just before dinner time. I could not have planned this better, even though I says so myself.” She raised her impeccable grin to the griffon called Wiff. “So, what’s on the menu today?”

To Moon’s panic, Wiff gave her exposed belly a long, ponderous lick. “Ah, perfect. Chubby yet not flabby. She’ll make for ideal burger filling.”

“Oh, not burgers again,” growled someone from the ranks. “That the only course you know to make of ponies? Let’s deep fry her! With those sliced potatoes they make in Prance!”

“Over my dead body!” snarled another griffon. “I swear, if I even see, gales forbid smell those things ever again I’ll retch my guts out. I demand we stuff the cunt!”

The culinary row quickly escalated into dishes Moon hadn’t even heard of before, and which she certainly would not wish to hear from ever again. Tears of fear smeared her vision at the thought of imminent death. How could she be so stupid as to fall for such an obvious ploy? Now her parents would never get to know what happened to her. On second thoughts, maybe that was a good thing. The last mental image she needed was her gravestone inscription reading something like “Here rests Cadet Moonbounce, who left the world in a deep fryer.”

Moon’s self-pity became interrupted as Silhouette’s voice cut through the quarrel. “Guys, guys, guys. Can’t we go about this like civilized people? I’m sure there is a certain recipe around which all of your suggestions more or less gravitate.”

“Burgers?” said Wiff hopefully.

Silhouette rolled her eyes, which then set to circle around the company. “Likely not. I’m referring to a bit more primal manner of consumption. A true griffon cuisine,” she said, her eyes stopping at Moonbounce. “Raw.”

The consenting murmur this raised chilled Moon to the core. As if the idea of being cooked and eaten wasn’t devastating enough: now there the promise of excruciating pain lingered heavily in the air too. Wiff’s slaver matted her fur again, this time along her leg. It could not end like this, she told herself. She couldn’t end up being torn apart and gobbled up by a flock of thugs. She had a life to live; a horizonful of plans to draw; mistakes to make and courses to take. She–

–bitt her tongue as Wiff ripped into her thigh with his beak, tearing off a gory chunk of sinew. He wolfed down the meat, licked the blood off of his beak, then nodded approvingly. The small crowd stirred like a pack of wolves over a kill.

“Just like the old times,” commented Wiff. He heaved the mare a few times in the air before tossing her high in a spray of blood. “Have at it!”

The screaming Moonbounce hardly reached the peak of her trajectory when the first griffons were already on her. Claws and beaks tore into her from every side, ripping, rending and slashing her soft flesh, at places to the bone, which soon enough shone from dozens of open, flooding wounds. Like a ragdoll trapped in the games of wild dogs, the batpony didn’t stand a chance. Piece by piece she vanished from existence, through a dozen hungry gullets until nought but the inedible bits remained, scattered around the warehouse.

On the ground, Silhouette gently leaned against Wiff. He didn’t need to recognize the gesture to get that the mare was in heat – her smell was telltale enough. It never clicked with him why witnessing butchering turned her on like that.

“Still hungry for some pony meat?” she cooed, nuzzling his feathers. “Maybe a little dessert…”

By chance Moonbounce’s head, finally torn loose from the neck, fell near Wiff, who caught it with one claw. He studied it thoughtfully, then pecked free the tongue hanging loosely out of her mouth. By his side, Silhouette purred at the sight, driving her muzzle against his bulk. As the horny mare moved down on him, Wiff kept chewing the decapitated head. It would be a good night ahead.
121111222112.title: Help her

12111122212.content:
“Last chance,” Moon warned. “Better start singing or I have to get nasty.”

“Go on, amuse me,” scoffed Silhouette.

Moonbounce cursed mentally. She hadn’t really expected the corporal to remain this steadfast with fangs on her throat. But if she backed now, Moon would lose all her credibility in her eyes. She couldn’t let herself be bossed around anymore – those roles were long due for a reversal.

“I knew you’d come to your senses,” said Silhouette as Moon’s fangs withdrew. “Now, be a good girl and – mhhph?”

The pegasus’s words were garbled as Moon’s muzzle stretched over hers. The batpony looked into the confused eyes below her, winked, and tucked her prey deeper in. Perhaps the prospect of one way trip down her gullet would be intimidating enough.

In the meantime there was nothing stopping Moon from cherishing the subtleties of the other mare’s taste. The agreeable piquant flavour reflected the pony’s personality remarkably. Moon took it all in eagerly, soon reaching the forehead, where her tongue stopped to explore the thin, delicate skin of eyelids. This incited the first serious struggles from the would-be meal, but Moon’s better position and generous figure outweighed the resistance easily, especially after Silhouette’s head squeezed into her esophagus. Such a satisfying torture made Moon emit a low moan. Together with the whine coming from her throat the sound reverberated pleasantly within her. The scarce words she could recognize implied the corporal had become willing to reconsider her recent decisions in life. It mattered none now – Moon simply had to get more of this treat.

After arriving to the shoulders it became increasingly difficult to keep wolfing down the pegasus, so Moon flopped onto her flank. The feeding resumed quickly from there, all the way to the wildly flapping wings, which she sucked in like wriggling spaghetti. The next delicacy of the meal was the slim, tight belly, which ended in an even tighter pussy. Moon drank the snug cleavage enthusiastically, incidentally driving her poor prey to the egde of orgasm. Her ultimate release was denied however as Moon gobbled up the hind legs, followed by the fluffy tail. After the final, drawn-out swallow the batpony rolled onto her back, her balloon of a belly sloshing and churning loudly as its occupant refused to settle down for good.

“You should’ve come clean when you had the chance,” teased Moon. A burp brought up the poignant taste and a couple of tealish feathers, which she spat out. “The only way you’re going anywhere now will be anything but tidy, let me tell you.”

A frustrated scream replied her from the confines of the stomach. The walls were beginning to contract around the pegasus, forcing her into a cramped, quivering lump with sharp outlines bulging out. Her head finally enclosed within the griffon’s. The overflowing saliva got into her mouth again, drowning her hopeless shouting. The room’s gloom gradually changed into the darkness of his esophagus. Moon kept her front legs out as long as she could, flailing for a grasp, for anything, even as the last sliver of light vanished behind the uvula. Her last, gurgling scream ran from the gaping beak, which snapped shut with the disappearance of her hooves. The griffon realigned his jaw, swallowed one more time, then watched as his belly expanded with the mass of the batpony. She wriggled admirably, probably because the digestive enzymes were already working on her skin, on their way to reducing her to meaty soup. The griffon sat on a nearby crate to relish the internal massage stirred by the dying struggles of the sweet bitch.

“I had a hunch you wouldn’t disappoint me,” he said, stroking the lump he assumed was the pony’s head. He could feel an opening gaping, which had to be mean she was fighting for the same air he felt the growing need to expel. “It’s been *burp* fun, but this is where we say farewells. Bye.”

A formidable belch exploded from his stomach into a thin cloud of stomach fluids, saliva, some hairs and an aftertaste of apple. The skin around his meal contracted, killing the mare’s last resistance. Her muzzle actually formed an imprint of sorts, where the shadow of the agony and terror she experienced were encapsulated. He knew she had passed as a certain tension relieved within him, leaving but a fully sated sensation behind. The griffon let out a few more smaller burps, then curled on the floor around his midsection. No one would come here for a few hours, which left just enough time to enjoy a little postprandial nap.
121111222212.title: Direct Approach

12111122222.content:
Moon realized that although plunging into the unknown might get her somewhere, it might not get her back, which was definitely what mattered more in the grand scheme of things. Eavesdropping had gotten her this far, right? There was no reason it would not see her all the way through.

Whether that was true or merely wishful thinking, Moon got never to know, for after some half an hour of idle waiting, the door to the bar opened discreetly. Shortly after the chair opposite to her was drawn out in the very particular way some unicorns do niche tasks to show off their unique abilities.

“Good evening, cadet,” said the mare seating herself in the table. She put her front hooves neatly in front of herself, corrected her ever so slightly posture, and gave Moonbounce a courteous smiles.

“Uhm… Good evening?” she replied in the lack of alternatives.

“Can I offer you anything?” the mare continued, speaking like an old friend. “I understand your kind fancies fruits?”

“Well, it’s the stereotype, but…”

“An apple juice it is,” the mare said, with nothing to suggest an order had been made. Nonetheless a glass of golden liquid was produced in between them without delay. Moon gave a suspicious glance first at the drink, then at the pony before her.

From voice to gaiters she had dressed herself like only the nobility of Canterlot could. The vest alone had to be worth what Moon made in a year, and it was simply criminal to think what all those jewelry had to cost. Everything about her radiated grandeur, which was precisely why Moon found its authenticity doubtful. Nopony who had to try that hard to look fancy couldn’t really be all that much.

“Well?” the pony asked. “Aren’t you going to ask already?”

Moon gave this a thought. Then she said, “Who are you?”

“I’m glad you asked. You see, I’m not going to give you my actual name, obviously, but it would be rude to withhold everything from you – especially considering I know so much about you – so why not call me Diamond?”

Right away Moon could tell two things about Diamond: she was good at pretending and excellent at dropping threats like needles.

Diamond drew a short breath before continuing. “Now, since you asked me a question, it’s only fair that I may return the favour. Ready for it? So, tell me, and tell me true: can you think of any single reason why I should let you walk out of here alive? Think hard, think good. I’m not going to ask twice.”
12111122222.title: Have Patience

121111222221.content:
“What?!” blurted Moonbounce before the shock would allow any other thought.

Diamond nodded over Moon’s shoulder. Immediately, a noose fell past her tufted ears, then fastened around her neck. She panicked as air stopped moving into her lungs and tried to get up. Instead, strong, taloned arms grabbed her and tied her hooves and wings, even as the rope on her neck kept pulling her towards the ceiling. When her feet lifted from the floor they were kicking in frenzy, her whole body twitching and spasming at the end of the noose.

In the table, Diamond took a sip of the juice while watching her flail. “Told you to think hard. As you see, it’s much neater than dancing hard.”

Odd laughter erupted at that. Moon heard none of it. All she heard was her mad heartbeats, her desperate, raspy gasps for breaths, the creaking of the tight rope as it hung from side to side along with her struggles. Bloodshot eyes bulging, she feverishly looked for salvation, but only found uncaring stares and excited grins. The tips of her hooves were inches from the planks; inches and miles, the same difference.

She was starting to lose it. The gags turned one after another shorter, sharper, and more painful. She could taste blood in her gaping mouth. Her neck felt like it was being bended by a gorilla. Black mist gathered at the edges of her spinning vision. Deep within her lungs, the ultimate appeal for oxygen surged upward, tearing its way with hooks made of glass, reaching from her gullet with one last dry gargle. With its passing, Moon’s corpse fell all limp, her wide open eyes staring at nothing, her saliva dribbling-tongue hanging past her lips.

“Get her down and feed to the pigs,” commented Diamond after an extremely brief silence. “Save the wings though. Seem like decent enough of leather. Who knows, maybe my tailor will be able to turn them into something useful, like a purse.”
121111222221.title: “What?!”

121111222222.content:
A flinch was all Moon’s face betrayed after she had bitten her own tongue to stay any ill-thought reactions it might be tempted to sprout. This was not a situation to be taken lightly. The threat was evanescent to pure reason, but in her spine Moon felt a tingling sensation much older and firmer than any sapience.

After some preciously slow yet intensive deliberation Moon replied: “If you did, I couldn’t buy the next round?”

This stirred some sniggering in the crowd the center of which their table had now become. To Moon’s eternal relief, Diamond soon joined chortle with a high-pitched giggle.

“A joke. Very clever. Very disarming. I like your thinking – it reminds me of my sister’s. Of course, eventually I had her buried alive in scorpions, so I wouldn’t trust that too much in the long run.” More laughter followed this, albeit this time from but a single throat.

Meanwhile Moon felt her own gullet had tried up for good, despite the juice she poured down on it, her hoof shaking tenderly. Furiously she tried to get on top of the situation. Who was this pony? What did she want? Had she really buried her sister in scorpions?

“Now you’re thinking whether I really buried my sister in scorpions,” continued Diamond. She smiled coily. “It’s an entrapping thought, isn’t it? Imagine what it must be like – swimming in a sea of seething stings, feeling them crawl all over your skin, digging into places you need a mirror to see into yourself… and then one of them wounds you. The rest go absolutely crazy! Soon you’re bleeding from a hundred cuts, each oozing burning poison, numbing your screams inside your lungs, breaking down your muscles, organs, eyes… leaving behind but a skeleton on which tiny legs skittle for the rest of eternity.”

At some point of her exposition, Diamond had closer her eyes dreamily. As she opened them, she found not only Moon but half the bar looking at her as if she had turned into a changeling. She returned them a confused expression.

“What? Did I say something funny?”

It wasn’t so much what you said as how you said it, thought Moon while biting her tongue again. It had seemed as if Diamond could have masturbated at the horrible words her mouth formed.

“Well, whatever,” said Diamond in the absence of answers. She turned renewed interest in Moonbounce, who had never before wanted to evaporate into thin air so much.

“I realize I’m straying from the topic at hoof, the topic being you. I like you. Or I think I like you, it’s always hard to tell, you know, when you like or actually hate someone. In either case you usually end up murdering them anyway, am I right?” The unicorn leaned forward. Her horn lit up sickly green. “Am I scaring you?”

“Yes,” whispered Moon, nailed on her seat.

“Good,” whispered Diamond back. “The right answer. They always get it right, that one. In my trade fear is what water is for sailors. You either float above or drown in it. You make it your bitch. Do you understand me?”

Moonbounce stared into the eyes illuminated by the magical neon-glow and saw madness. Pure, simple madness imprisoned in spider webs which might tear open at any moment by a lunatic spider ravaging its own house in search or a fly that wasn’t there. There was no reading a mind like that. The actions such a force demanded were completely opposite to understanding.
121111222222.title: Hold your tongue

1211112222221.content:
“Yes,” Moon stuttered. “I understand perfectly.”

“Marvelous,” said Diamond. “Then this next part should come as no surprise.”

“Wait, what are you–”

A vaporous stench of something very rotten blew at Moon’s face as, right before her face, Diamond gaped open her mouth, revealing her an ample view of her pulsing throat, that seemingly bottomless abyss over which an uvula hung idly, like pointing the way in. The smell wafting from there was unlike what Moon had ever sniffed; it brought to mind rancid meat. Coming from what presumably was a vegetarian stomach, the notion was alarming to say the least. Not as alarming as the fact that the unicorn had frozen Moon stiff with her horn, but still, quite distrustful in its own ominous way.

“Smell that?” Diamond spoke, closing her mouth slightly. “Before I was informed of the complications your unexpected reappearance here caused in my subjects, I was quite enjoying myself in a party not far from here. Especially the menu had me occupied. Why, some of the dishes practically begged to be eaten! In fact most of them were begging the exact opposite, but figuratively speaking… eh, you get the idea. The point is, I was not unable to finish, not by a long shot, of what by rights was supposed to be a night I had been awaiting for a handsome while. And it has made my hunger so very much, much more noticeable.”

The jaws parted again, this time more than Moon’s eyes could believe, and more than her mind wanted to. Forced by the unbending magic, her head was brought within the tasting range of the slavering chops. Diamond’s tongue snapped forward eagerly, blindly lapping wherever it could reach, including Moon’s nostrils, teeth, lips and chin. It chilled Moon to realize she was actually being tasted by another pony, utterly without restraint or concern for the concept of respect for another fellow equine. All she could do was twitch her eyelids and watch as her face became rapidly coated in foreign saliva.

Suddenly there was a yank. Moon’s muzzle sank into the moistness before her, with two rows of flat teeth clamping on her from above and below. Slowly and deliberately they begun chewing her – not quite painfully, but with an experimenting, curious intent that removed the last doubts of whether Diamond was being serious or not.

“Hmmhmh-not-hhmmh-bad,” commented Diamond amidst her efforts. “Tastes-hmhm-like apples.”

The batpony screamed internally as more of her head bulged the other’s mare’s powdered cheeks. Thoughts glowing with anger and fear, she tried to resist the arcane powers curbing her muscles, but the stupid horn was more powerful than what she had ever had to encounter before. The last glimpse Moon had of the outside world was the sight of the spiralled bone overwatching her imminent sliding into the slick depths reeking unimaginably awful.

The worst of it wasn’t the stench of decay alone, but the knowledge Moon enjoyed of its origin. Her keen sense of smell now turned into a foul curse, for she could pick up several distinct aromas under the overwhelming wave of digesting meat, including french cream, some vegetables, fruit, even a few spices. The poor pony Diamond has feasted on had been cooked by a first class chef. I instead will be served raw like the day I was born.

Diamond had to realign her focus as the unfinished meal decided to turn ill-mannered. It was impressive the pony could so much as tremble under her horn, least so much as cause her to notice her struggles. If nothing else, the little fight fuelled the unicorn’s appetite. Gathering some strength, she gave the batpony the first proper swallow, sending her forehead down into her gullet where it formed a noticeable bulge. Novel ground conquered, Diamond set out to quickly harvest its fruit, leaving not an inch of the delicious neck fur untasted.

Unbearable tightness combined with oppressive humidity to deprive Moon of the sherds of her psychic cohesion. The fragrance of the late diet invaded her nostrils completely, from there her brain and good sense. She saw herself as but a raw steak, a portion of flesh trapped in a sac of corrosive acids shredding her groomed fur, eating away her beautiful skin, dissolving her sensitive entrails, eyes and all other soft bits, leaving behind a pile of corroded bones, a clump of hair and four pairs of hooves. The rest would be turned into fat around the very belly that had digested her, with the leftovers unloaded back into the cycle of nature. The idea was a flash in Moon’s head, like a knife: quick to disappear, slow to heal. She wailed at the sheer insanity of it.

Meanwhile, Diamond had progressed to accommodate her prey’s shoulders, one at a time. As she worked one joint after another, a problem presented itself attached to the pony’s back. Those leathery appendages didn’t look appetizing at all. If anything they looked like the makings of a new purse. But for that purpose they would have to end up in a different address than where their current owner was heading to. Unceremoniously reaching for her bag, Diamond produced a pair of scissors she always carried around for situations not completely alien to the present one. Securing the mare within her with one more swallow, she put the blades to work.

As one the crowd in the room grimaced while the bat pony’s wings were severed from her back and dropped onto the floor, where a pool of blood quickly enlarged. Deep within her, Diamond could hear agonized screams resonate. They tickled slightly. In any case, the time had come to finish this particular dinner, and the fresh blood was just the lubrication she needed to do that. Standing up and using her magic to align the pony better, the unicorn fed her straight down her throat in a series of heaving gulps. Soon all but remained were a pair of stiff hind legs sticking out along with the tip of a black tail. Diamond sucked them all inside like spaghetti, then steadied herself as the newly acquired mass settled itself into the most economical position in her swollen belly. Only when she was certain her stomach could handle the load, she let her magic lose control of it.

Immediately a jolt-like scramble began down there, joined with more screaming. Imprints of hoof pads and facial features appeared on her tightly stretched skin, only to bounce back in short order. It was all too little all too late. Nonetheless, the struggle did have one beneficial side: aiding the excess air exit more easily. Sure enough, Diamond felt pressure climbing up, then explode in a mighty belch heavy with saliva, hairs, and the tainted badge of the cop-bitch. The piece of silver clattered on the floor for about as long as the last row in her belly lasted. Afterwards, only the deep rumbling of acids in their work followed.

“This would probably be time for some clever remark,” burped Diamond. “Can’t think of any. Oh well, not that she was that special a case to begin with.”
1211112222221.title: Answer yes

121112.content:
“Tell me more about these kidnappings,” Moonbounce said. “How come they’re just ‘possible’?”

“Perhaps I should start from the beginning,” said Nox, leaning back on his chair. “The first report of a missing pony arrived three days ago. A mare in her twenties got lost on her way back from the circus that had arrived to town earlier the same day. She had a coltfriend along, according to whom Cake Walk (her name) disappeared in the bar they went into after the show. One moment she was there, the other not. He isn’t that specific about details though, him having been drunk most of the evening. The two other cases have some similarities to the first. Young mares, moving with a friend or two, on their way back from the circus at night, vanish at some point without the others knowing anything about it. You can read all about it from here,” Nox finished, pulling a file from his drawer and hoofing it to Moon.

“And the kidnappings are just possible because there hasn’t been any ransom demands,” she said after leafing through the thin file.

“Correct,” said Nox with a smile that said she had passed a test of some sort. “There’s some who wouldn't even consider the cases related, but my gut says that they are, and that the circus is the glue. We’ve questioned the people there of course, other audience members included. Seems to be nothing out of place going in there. Which is exactly what I find so suspicious.”

“So… How should we proceed?”

“I have a plan,” said Nox, with a face Moon had trouble reading. “A slightly unconventional one, but that’s precisely what we need with an unconventional case, isn't it? Well, I’m not going to beat around the bush: I want you to go to the circus, undercover, with a partner, and see if you can arouse the kidnapper’s attention.”

Moon’s jaw dropped. “Wait… You want to use me as a bait?!”

“I said undercover,” said Nox calmly but sternly. “And yes, as a bait too. That’s the unconventional part. The thing is, the clock is ticking, and we need to get results. Three lives are at stake here, cadet. You’ve sworn to protect them. Will you stand up to the task?”

Nox had her cornered, Moon realized. If she refused, she’d let down the Guard on her first night on duty. That wasn’t an option. So, like her mother had always said, when there’s only one thing to be done, you do it.

“Yessir,” she said, and saluted.

“I knew I could count on you, cadet,” he said with the characteristic grin. “It’s all set then. I’ve already picked a partner who will act as your coltfriend tonight. The show starts in an hour, so you two have a short while to mingle and get your act together.”

Moonbounce bit her lip. “Sir… What do you expect me to do there, exactly?”

Nox shrugged. “To be yourself: a young, cheery gal having a night out with her coltfriend. I’d tell you to look cute, but you got that covered already. Put on something suggestive. Comb your mane too, it looks messy. That’s your facade. Inside, you keep your wits near you. Keep an eye out for anything strange. I swear, all’s not right with that circus.”

“O-kay…” said Moon. “And this ‘coltfriend’ of mine: who’s it going to be?”

Nox’s grin spread to his ears. “Why, me of course. Now go and get yourself as pretty as you can; we’ll set off in forty.”



***




When they told me the Guard would be the place to show off my assets, this wasn’t what I had in mind, thought Moonbounce as she walked side by side with Nox towards a huge tent lit with colorful lights. She wore a dark-blue miniskirt which rather emphasized than covered the generous form of her rump. Four pairs of black kneesocks with pictures of bats in them covered her hooves. According to Nox, those had been a necessary addition, although he had been somewhat vague as to why this was. In the end, she didn’t even care to know.

On the other hoof, seen from a certain perspective there were worse predicaments than her current one. The pay of a cadet earned a living but not much in the way of entertainment, and it had been years since she had been to a circus. The night had a promise of beauty in the air, and the few drinks Nox had offered her “to increase the authenticity of our infiltration” made her feel lighter than usual in the head. And to top it all, on a closer look, her escort didn’t look all that bad in a suite.

“Brace yourself,” he was saying. “We’re going in.”

Inside, Moon had to gasp, first at the sheer size of the tent, then at the bare splendour of it. The ceiling had to be at least twenty meters above them, and most of the vast space was filled with blinking lights, open fires, and acrobats soaring from a rope to rope in the middle of their warm-ups. For a moment she was but a filly again, eager to be amazed at everything.

But that could not be. She had a job to do, after all, even if she was doing it in kneesocks with bats in them. Already she had spotted a few clowns at the edge of the ring who harbored a suspiciously keen interest in a cannon. And that cotton candy seller was laughing way too loudly for her taste. Even some of the audience had an air of guilt about them.

“Seeing anything?” she whispered at Nox as they seated themselves.

“Yeah,” said the Sergeant. “I see plenty, alright. That skirt sure leaves no room for imagination.”

She stared at him, incredulous. There was no telling if that had been a sorry attempt at a joke, an effort to keep in character or a blatant vulgarity. They were on a serious mission, after all. But that didn’t seem to stop the unmistakable bulge in the Sergeant’s pants betraying the less professional side of his thoughts.

For her luck the awkward moment passed as the clowns fired the cannon (with one of their smaller kin inside) and thus launched the show. While Moonbounce the cadet paid attention to every shade of suspicion, Moonbounce the filly wore out her eyes while consuming all the wonders of the spectacle. The acrobats toyed with gravity and life in equal measure: the clowns had gravestones (literally) laughing at their goofes. The magicians displayed the arcane arts at the apex of their glory. The circus even included a score of rare, magical beasts, like a manticore, a hydra, a cocatrice and a chimera. The stunts the animal trainers did with the monsters could only make her wonder how none of them got eaten on the spot.

The show went on, on and on until it didn’t anymore. Moonbounce was still coming down from the heights the experience had her lifted as she and the Nox joined the current on ponies leaving the tent. But before they could get to the streets, the Sergeant suddenly pulled her aside.

“Don’t drift off, cadet,” he said. “Our work has just begun. Now, I want you to start wandering around the nearby streets, preferably quiet ones, looking like you’ve lost your way. If anypony makes contact with you, play it smart; let them try and help you, see if they’ll try anything.”

“Yessir,” said Moon. A bit more hesitantly she added: “Will you be watching over me?”

“No. I’ll take a look around the tent and the backstage. If I don’t find anything, I’ll seek you out. Now go.”

Moon watched the Sergeant melt into the crowd. Granted, she had not know him for long, but already she could tell Nox was not your average, shout-and-spit-a-lot kind of Sergeant. His behavior back in the tent still nagged her, but perhaps a hint of coarseness was something she had to get used to in the Guard. In any case, like he had said, she had a mission to accomplish, although she still wasn’t quite sure what it was exactly. To be honest, wandering aimlessly around the streets wasn’t what her excited mind was in mood for right now. She had done enough observing in the tent already. She craved for action.

On the other hoof… that would sort of be like breaking a direct command…
121112.title: Take the Case of Kidnappings

1211121.content:
…And on the other hoof, the aforementioned command of playing the damsel in distress was suspect enough to merit a bit of distance from her part, Moonbounce decided. If Nox seriously thought she’d play the part of the bait like a little filly, well, he was wrong. And when she’d solve this case, he’d have to admit his error to her face.

As the audience departed and left the clearing mostly quiet, Moon slipped into the shadows. If Nox’s gut had the sniff of truth it boasted, there would have to be some clues in the tent’s vicinity, or perhaps in the camp they had set in the nearby park. Three ponies would not just vanish off the face of the earth.
1211121.title: Orders, bah!

12111211.content:
The most natural place to begin the search would of course be the tent itself. Who knew, perhaps she could fish information out of the employees in a casual conversation, or find some other hint of the missing ponies’ fates. Adamant in her effort to act like a real investigator, she slashed a cut into the canvas with a claw of her wing and stepped in.

Most of the lights had already gone out, leaving the interior of the tent wrapped in gloom. Sneaking beneath the rows of seats, Moon circled the main ring, her night vision scanning the site for movement. Her ears turned out of their own accord, alert for the tiniest of sounds. All around her, the darkness loomed, as if holding its breath.

Something rattled on the other side of the tent. Moon froze, peering through the seats to see what it was, but nothing stuck out from the dim background of crates, circus equipment and cages. She waited with bated breath, her every sense wired to the extreme. Nothing stirred in the silence; not even the big water pool at the centre of the stage, which the clowns had left there after their last show.

Maybe if I fly to that pole I can get a better look around, she reasoned. She could fly quieter than a leaf would fall, after all. With her wings spread out, she practically glided upwards until she landed on the round platform at the top of the central pole. At the same moment, something clanged below her. Automatically, she focused her eagle eyes at one of the crates.

From a hole in the wooden side, something looked back at her. Moon blinked, a sudden dizziness and cold capturing her on the spot. She couldn’t stop staring. A sense of dread spread over her, starting weirdly from the legs. She tried to look away from that slit, but for her life couldn’t, as if something forced her eyes to look straight in. A numb, heavy sensation climbed up her feet. Mustering all her willpower, she looked down from the corner of her eye.

With astounding velocity, her legs were turning to stone; into gray, hard, cold granite. It was already up her knees. She knew it was impossible, completely ridiculous, yet it was happening. Right now. And yet she could not look away from that, that, that… crate which read, in big bold letters, “Don’t look: a cocatrice inside”.

Concentrating her every brain cell, she broke the eye contact with the box. It was too late though; her legs were but dead weight now. Carried by the momentum, she swayed from side to side, the terror of immobility squeezing her throat. Under her, the planks complained loudly. And then she fell.

With the help of her wings and the ropes crisscrossing the air, Moon succeeded in slowing down her acceleration so that she didn’t end up as a wet smear on the ground below. But with all her limbs stiff as rock, there was no helping the crash, which ended at the center of the water pool. The splash she made echoed around and removed a good quarter of the liquid in one go. Unfortunately, that left still plenty enough for her body to immerse completely.

Luna’s craters, she thought in horror. I can’t move! I can’t move!

It wasn’t completely true. Her left wing whipped the surface furiously, and whatever part of her hadn’t turned to stone thrashed as in fever. She was but a meter deep, yet she might’ve as well been laying in the bottom of the ocean. Eyes wide she stared at the shimmering surface, cheeks bulging from the little, precious air she had gulped during the drop. It was running out fast. Already her lungs ached; soon they’d be burning. She fought against the instinct as best as she could, but in the end, the reflex kicked in, and she breathed out.

Water gushed into her throat instantaneously. Her scream rose with a pillar of bubbles, unheard. On the surface, the lone wing that hadn’t been crushed under her body went briefly mad, then stiffened, then fell limp. From the bottom of the pool, glazed ember eyes stared at nothing.
12111211.title: Look into the tent

12111212.content:
If the circus folk indeed had something to do with the disappearances, they probably wouldn’t leave evidence of it at a place they expected hundreds of ponies come visiting, reasoned Moonbounce. Their camp, however, could well contain things of interest.

It was customary for travelling groups, even whole circuses, to accommodate in Canterlot’s public space. The city had plenty of open parks capable of hosting a generous number of people, so why not put them to use when the need arose. The Cinnamon park, named for the spices that grew there, was among the more popular locations for camps. It had well, and it wasn’t too close to any apartment buildings. Conveniently for Moonbounce, it also had lots of bushes to sneak around.

A large fire had been set in the middle of the camp, gathering people around it to sing, chat and booze. There were all sorts; muscular acrobats, fat clowns, solitary magicians and other, less recognizable figures. It occurred to Moon that perhap the missing ponies had simply ran away and joined the circus. It seemed like a lot of fun.

“Hello there, cutie,” said a rough voice behind her. Moon flinched, whirling around.

“Uhm, hello to yourself,” she said uncertainly, eyeing the stallion who had appeared behind her. There was not many a pony who could sneak up on her like that.

“Well?” the stallion said after a moment’s silence. From his slur it was clear he had been drinking. “Go on. Ask away.”

“Uhh,” started Moon. “What should I be asking?”

The stallion snorted. “You want to join the party, right? You don’t have to hide in the bushes to do that. Come on, don’t be shy: I’ll introduce you to the rest of lot.”

Moon blinked. It did seem like a good opportunity to infiltrate the camp. Perhaps too good. The stallion, one of the acrobats by the look of his muscles, seemed genuine enough, but she could not shut down the doubt that not all was right with him. What should she do?
12111212.title: Look into the camp

121112121.content:
“Thanks!” she said cheerily. “Gosh, I can be so shy at times. I’ve been sitting here forever, just rolling my hooves. Thank Luna you happened by, Mister…?”

“Clear,” he replied. A swaying hoof was extended between them. “Steer Clear.”

“Nice to meet you, Steer,” she mused. It was apparent she was arousing more than politeness in the stud, so why not take full advantage of it. She accepted the hoof graciously. “They call me Cherry.”

“I bet they do,” he said, still shaking her hoof. The grip of the pony could have crushed a small tree. “I bet they do.”

And just like that, she had made her way into the camp. The welcome was fierce and merry, and in mere minutes she felt like being one of the flock. Maybe the drink they pushed on her from the start had something to do with it. She couldn’t refuse of course, although the liquid burned her throat with every gulp. It had to be homemade. With everypony drunk she’d be sure to tease answers from them with innocent questions. If only she could remember what those were, or why she had to ask them, or why she was here to begin with.
